instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no start, power cycles every 5s
threads.message:
Hi smart guys

Recently I spilled beer on my old macbook and now want to fix it. I am a hardware designer and dont do repairs, so no experience in troubleshooting. Please, help me with it.

So <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 13 inch Macbook Pro Retina. It was on when I spilled bear and it immediately shut itself off. Took me about an hour to get to home and teardown. I was surprised how much of green corrosion grew for such short time, most of corrosion was around INA current sensors and mosfets at top part of pcb (where air vents), some around components around smc but not much. After cleaning pcb visually all is ok and not much damage. I found a broken connection on one of INA, but no changes after fixing connection. I checked <CHIP>U5410</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5400</CHIP> where were most of corrosion and I see with osciloscope that they works fine. I also checked a few voltage sense circuits to make sure their signals goes all the way to smc.

No boot.
Green light on charger than switches to amber(no battery connected)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.56V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.09V (when I measure it in diferent parts of pcb I see slightly diferent voltage)
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PPV5_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and other S5 and G3Hs are good and present.
All others S0..S4 powerails are off but jumps to designed voltage every 5s for a 200ms pulse.
I did not spot any damage component or short.
For me it feels like SMC tries to go to S0 state, but senses wrong voltage/current and shuts everything off, than cycle repeats in 5 seconds. Or it is indeed has a short circuit on one of sub rails.

Any ideas what to check?

Thanks in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no start, power cycles every 5s
threads.message: Hm, after some more playing I found that <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is not starting. It is strange as I think I saw vcore before. Now it is just off. MAX15119GTM receives power and EN pin but does not trigger mosfets and does not output PGOOD. That I think the reason it stays in power cycle.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no start, power cycles every 5s
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

To discard SMC sensors problem, try starting in SMC bypass mode.
Test the board alone on the desk, nothing connected (apart of charger).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no start, power cycles every 5s
threads.message:
I worked with it on desk when nothing is connected (only charger).
1 time board started (fans starts to spin), but after reconnecting the charger, it is same again.
It is first time I hear about SMC bypass, what is the right procedure? Should I connect keyboard and keep power button for 5-10seconds? The thing is that I am not sure keyboard is still alive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no start, power cycles every 5s
threads.message:
Hm. Thanks for the suggestion. I tried to connect charger while holding power button and now it behaves differently. It still does not work, but fans spins much longer and now I see activity from <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, so seems my suggestion that <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is bad was wrong.
But it still does power cycles every 5s

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no start, power cycles every 5s
threads.message:
How much time stays on in SMC bypass?
You have something corroded; check pages 43 & 44 in schematic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no start, power cycles every 5s
threads.message:
Checked with oscilloscope, it is not longer. Same 200ms. I think fans just starts with max speed during SMC bypass and that gave me wrong impression that it works longer.
I checked <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> with oscilloscope, voltages goes to 1.2v for 50ms than slowly discharges back to 0.
Are you sure about page 43 & 44? In schematics that I have there is no page 43, and 44 has peripheral connectors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no start, power cycles every 5s
